Use Blockchain technology for safe interact with ecological assets and obligations, carbon markets

More

Carbon markets now and in the near future

Probably the largest global commodity market in the foreseeable future (up to $10 trillion at maturity)

Currently 17 ETS, covering 54 jurisdictions. By 2017, up to 20% of global emissions will be covered by carbon markets

More than 40 different carbon compliance units representing fundamentally universal underlying asset – the right to emit 1 tCO2e

Dozens of platforms: registries, tracking services systems, exchanges, auctioning platforms

Carbon Dioxide
Data source: NASA

Direct measurements: 2005-2016

Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an important heat-trapping (greenhouse) gas, which is released through human activities such as deforestation and burning fossil fuels, as well as natural processes such as respiration and volcanic eruptions. The chart above shows CO2 levels in recent years, with average seasonal cycle removed.

Time series: 2002-2014

The time series shows global distribution and variation of the concentration of mid-tropospheric carbon dioxide in parts per million (ppm). The overall color of the map shifts toward the red with advancing time due to the annual increase of CO2.

Global Temperature
Data source: NASA

Global land-ocean temperature index 1880-2015

This graph illustrates the change in global surface temperature relative to 1951-1980 average temperatures. The 10 warmest years in the 134-year record all have occurred since 2000, with the exception of 1998. The year 2015 ranks as the warmest on record. (Source: NASA/GISS). This research is broadly consistent with similar constructions prepared by the Climatic Research Unit and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Time series: 1885-2015

The time series above shows the five-year average variation of global surface temperatures from 1885 to 2015. Dark blue indicates areas cooler than average. Dark red indicates areas warmer than average.

Arctic Sea Ice
Data source: NASA

Average September extent 1979-2016

Arctic sea ice reaches its minimum each September. September Arctic sea ice is now declining at a rate of 13.3 percent per decade, relative to the 1981 to 2010 average. The graph above shows the average monthly Arctic sea ice extent in September since 1979, derived from satellite observations. The 2012 extent is the lowest in the satellite record.

Time series: 1979-2015

The time series above shows the annual Arctic sea ice minimum since 1979, based on satellite observations. The 2012 sea ice extent is the lowest in the satellite record.

Land Ice
Data source: NASA

Antarctica mass variation since 2002

Data from NASA's GRACE satellites show that the land ice sheets in both Antarctica and Greenland are losing mass. The continent of Antarctica (left chart) has been losing about 134 gigatonnes of ice per year since 2002, while the Greenland ice sheet (right) has been losing an estimated 287 gigatonnes per year. (Source: GRACE satellite data)

Greenland mass variation since 2002

Sea Level
Data source: NASA

Ground data: 1870-2000

Sea level rise is caused primarily by two factors related to global warming: the added water from melting land ice and the expansion of sea water as it warms. The above chart, derived from coastal tide gauge data, shows how much sea level changed from about 1870 to 2000.

Satellite data: 1993-2016

This chart tracks the change in sea level since 1993 as observed by satellites.

Accounting systems of ecological, carbon assets and liabilities

Functioning and multiplying
Private voluntary programs

Scattered program with mutually incompatible demands and low liquidity instruments

Functioning and multiplying
Required system

Separated systems, non-conjugated with each other, with strict administrative control and high transaction costs

New way
Distributed Blockchain network

It solves the problem of fraud, double counting of assets, with the participation of many players in the market. Unlimited interoperability and systems integration, and conversion tools on the individual choice of the participants. Low transaction costs of investment operations.

We created decentralized Blockchain platform for interacting with ecological assets and liabilities, carbon registries

DAO IPCI provides direct interaction of all members with the ecological assets and liabilities, carbon registries stored in Blockchain. This technology allows to ensure the transparency of transactions for all market participants, and to synchronize the work of various carbon registries worldwide.

Functions of Operator in Program

На базе платформы создан интерфейс, в котором Оператор осуществляет свои функции:

  • утверждает создание нового реестра и выпуск заверенных Аудитором единиц в пределахлимита;
  • утверждает Эмитента для доступа на площадку транзакций (рынок);
  • утверждает перечень аккредитованных Аудиторов.

Все операции прозрачны и защищены, осуществляются посредством смарт-контрактов.

DAO IPCI release 0.1.0

API для внедрения покупки углеродных единиц на ваш сайт

Практически любая услуга или товар несут за собой углеродный след.

Внедрив API DAO IPCI на сайт для безопасного приобретения углеродных единиц, вы можете дать возможность своим пользователям погашать свой углеродный след в один клик.

Чтобы воспользоваться нашим бесплатным API, вы можете скачать код на GitHub или связаться с нашим специалистом.
